title: Rosin
text:
Rosin (), also called colophony or Greek pitch (), is a solid form of <a href="resin">resin</a> obtained from <a href="pine">pine</a>s and some other <a href="plant">plant</a>s, mostly <a href="Pinophyta">conifers</a>, produced by heating fresh liquid resin to vaporize the <a href="Volatility%20%28chemistry%29">volatile</a> liquid <a href="terpene">terpene</a> components. It is semi-transparent and varies in color from yellow to black. At room temperature rosin is brittle, but it melts at stove-top temperature. It chiefly consists of various <a href="resin%20acid">resin acid</a>s, especially <a href="abietic%20acid">abietic acid</a>. The term "colophony" comes from "", Latin for "resin from <a href="Colophon%20%28city%29">Colophon</a>" ( "Kolophōnia rhētinē"), an ancient <a href="Ionia">Ionic</a> city.
Properties.
Rosin is <a href="brittle">brittle</a> and <a href="friable">friable</a>, with a faint piny odor. It is typically a <a href="glass">glass</a>y solid, though some rosins will form <a href="crystal">crystal</a>s, especially when brought into solution. The practical melting point varies with different specimens, some being semi-fluid at the temperature of boiling water, others melting at 100 °C to 120 °C. It is very flammable, burning with a smoky flame, so care should be taken when melting it. It is soluble in <a href="ethanol">alcohol</a>, <a href="diethyl%20ether">ether</a>, <a href="benzene">benzene</a> and <a href="chloroform">chloroform</a>.
Rosin consists mainly of <a href="abietic%20acid">abietic acid</a>, and combines with caustic <a href="alkali">alkali</a>s to form salts (<a href="rosinate">rosinate</a>s or <a href="pinate">pinate</a>s) that are known as <a href="rosin%20soap">rosin soap</a>s. In addition to its extensive use in <a href="soap%20making">soap making</a>, rosin is largely employed in making <a href="varnishes">varnishes</a> (including fine violin varnishes), <a href="sealing%20wax">sealing wax</a> and various <a href="adhesive">adhesive</a>s. It is also used for preparing shoemakers' <a href="wax">wax</a>, for pitching <a href="lager">lager</a> beer <a href="casks">casks</a>, and numerous other purposes such as providing backing surfaces to tin ware, copper ware, or even silver and gold vessels when embossing or engraving them. Its relatively low melting point, and firm solid form allows liquid rosin to be poured into the vessel, and when cooled allows embossing or engraving of the vessel without deforming the vessel - even if it has a skin which is quite thin. Afterwards, the object can be reheated in an oven, and the rosin poured out for reuse. Any remaining rosin film can easily be rinsed away with alcohol or other solvents. 
Rosin is also sometimes used as internal reinforcement for very thin skinned metal objects - things like silver, copper or tin plate candlesticks, or sculptures, where it is simply melted, poured into a hollow thin-skinned object, and left to harden.
Prolonged exposure to rosin fumes released during soldering can cause <a href="occupational%20asthma">occupational asthma</a> (formerly called "colophony disease" in this context) in sensitive individuals, although it is not known which component of the fumes causes the problem.
The type of rosin used with bowed string instruments is determined by the diameter of the strings. Generally this means that the larger the instrument is, the softer the rosin should be. For instance, <a href="double%20bass">double bass</a> rosin is generally soft enough to be <a href="wikt%3Apliable">pliable</a> with slow movements. A cake of bass rosin left in a single position for several months will show evidence of flow, especially in warmer weather.
Prolonged exposure to rosin, by handling rosin-coated products, such as <a href="laser%20printer">laser printer</a> or photocopying paper, can give rise to a form of industrial <a href="contact%20dermatitis">contact dermatitis</a>.
Uses.
Rosin is an ingredient in <a href="printing">printing</a> <a href="ink">ink</a>s, photocopying and laser printing paper, <a href="varnish">varnish</a>es, <a href="adhesive">adhesive</a>s (glues), <a href="soap">soap</a>, <a href="sizing">paper sizing</a>, <a href="Soft%20drink">soda</a>, <a href="solder">solder</a>ing <a href="Flux%20%28metallurgy%29">fluxes</a>, and <a href="sealing%20wax">sealing wax</a>.
Rosin can be used as a <a href="glazing%20agent">glazing agent</a> in <a href="medicine">medicine</a>s and <a href="chewing%20gum">chewing gum</a>. It is denoted by <a href="E%20number">E number</a> E915. A related <a href="Glycerol%20esters%20of%20wood%20rosins">glycerol ester (E445)</a> can be used as an <a href="emulsifier">emulsifier</a> in <a href="soft%20drink">soft drink</a>s. In <a href="pharmaceutical">pharmaceutical</a>s, rosin forms an ingredient in several plasters and ointments.
In industry, rosin is a <a href="flux%20%28metallurgy%29">flux</a> used in <a href="soldering">soldering</a>. The <a href="lead">lead</a>-<a href="tin">tin</a> <a href="solder">solder</a> commonly used in electronics has 1 to 2% rosin by weight as a flux core, helping the <a href="melting">molten</a> <a href="metal">metal</a> flow and making a better connection by <a href="redox">reducing</a> the refractory solid <a href="oxide">oxide</a> layer formed at the surface back to metal. It is frequently seen as a burnt or clear residue around new soldering.
A mixture of <a href="pitch%20%28resin%29">pitch</a> and rosin is used to make a surface against which <a href="glass">glass</a> is <a href="polishing">polish</a>ed when making optical components such as <a href="lens%20%28optics%29">lenses</a>.
Rosin is added in small quantities to traditional <a href="linseed%20oil">linseed oil</a>/sand gap fillers ("mastic"), used in building work.
When mixed with waxes and oils, rosin is the main ingredient of "mystic smoke", a gum which, when rubbed and suddenly stretched, appears to produce puffs of <a href="smoke">smoke</a> from the fingertips.
Rosin is extensively used for its <a href="friction">friction</a>-increasing capacity in several fields: 
Other uses that are not based on friction: 
Rosin and its derivatives also exhibit wide-ranging pharmaceutical applications. Rosin derivatives show excellent film forming and coating properties. They are also used for tablet film and enteric coating purpose. Rosins have also been used to formulate microcapsules and nanoparticles.
<a href="Glycerol">Glycerol</a>, <a href="sorbitol">sorbitol</a>, and <a href="mannitol">mannitol</a> esters of rosin are used as <a href="chewing%20gum">chewing gum</a> bases for medicinal applications. The degradation and <a href="biocompatibility">biocompatibility</a> of rosin and rosin-based biomaterials has been examined in vitro and ex vivo.
Production.
Rosin is the resinous constituent of the <a href="oleoresin">oleo-resin</a> exuded by various species of <a href="pine">pine</a>, known in commerce as crude <a href="turpentine">turpentine</a>. The separation of the oleo-resin into the <a href="essential%20oil">essential oil</a> (spirit of turpentine) and common rosin is accomplished by <a href="distillation">distillation</a> in large copper <a href="still">still</a>s. The essential oil is carried off at a temperature of between ° and , leaving fluid rosin, which is run off through a tap at the bottom of the still, and purified by passing through straining wadding. Rosin varies in color, according to the age of the tree from which the turpentine is drawn and the degree of heat applied in distillation, from an <a href="Opacity%20%28optics%29">opaque</a>, almost pitch-black substance through grades of brown and yellow to an almost perfectly transparent colorless glassy mass. The commercial grades are numerous, ranging by letters from A (the darkest) to N (extra pale), superior to which are W (window glass) and WW (water-white) varieties, the latter having about three times the value of the common qualities.
Tall oil rosin is produced during the distillation of <a href="tall%20oil">crude tall oil</a>, a by-product of the <a href="kraft%20paper">kraft paper</a> making process.
When pine trees are harvested "the resinous portions of fallen or felled trees like longleaf and slash pines, when allowed to remain upon the ground, resist decay indefinitely." This "stump waste", through the use of <a href="destructive%20distillation">destructive distillation</a> or solvent processes, can be used to make products including rosin. This type of rosin is typically called wood rosin.
Because the turpentine and pine oil from destructive distillation "become somewhat contaminated with other distillation products", solvent processes are commonly used. In this process, stumps and roots are chipped and soaked in the light end of the heavy <a href="naphtha">naphtha</a> fraction (boiling between ( and ) from a crude <a href="oil%20refinery">oil refinery</a>. Multi-stage counter-current <a href="solid%20phase%20extraction">extraction</a> is commonly used. In this process, fresh naphtha first contacts wood leached in intermediate stages, and naphtha laden with rosin from intermediate stages contacts unleached wood before <a href="vacuum%20distillation">vacuum distillation</a> to recover naphtha from the rosin, along with <a href="fatty%20acid">fatty acid</a>s, turpentine, and other constituents later separated through <a href="steam%20distillation">steam distillation</a>. Leached wood is steamed for additional naphtha recovery prior to burning for energy recovery. After the solvent has been recovered, "the terpene oils are separated by <a href="fractional%20distillation">fractional distillation</a> and recovered mainly as refined turpentine, dipentene, and pine oil. The nonvolatile residue from the extract is wood rosin of rather dark color. Upgrading of the rosin is carried out by clarification methods that generally may include bed-filtering or <a href="furfural">furfural</a>-treatment of rosin-solvent solution."
On a large scale, rosin is treated by destructive distillation for the production of rosin spirit, pinoline and <a href="rosin%20oil">rosin oil</a>. The last enters into the composition of some of the solid lubricating <a href="Grease%20%28lubricant%29">grease</a>s, and is also used as an <a href="adulterant">adulterant</a> of other oils.
The chief region of <a href="Resin%20extraction">rosin production</a> includes <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, southern <a href="China">China</a> (such as <a href="Guangdong">Guangdong</a>, <a href="Guangxi">Guangxi</a>, <a href="Fujian">Fujian</a>, <a href="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> and <a href="Jiangxi">Jiangxi</a>), and the northern part of <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>. Chinese rosin is obtained mainly from the <a href="turpentine">turpentine</a> of <a href="Masson%27s%20pine">Masson's pine</a> "Pinus massoniana" and <a href="slash%20pine">slash pine</a> "P. elliottii".
The <a href="South%20Atlantic%20States">South Atlantic</a> and eastern <a href="Gulf%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">Gulf states</a> of the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> is a second chief region of production. American rosin is obtained from the turpentine of <a href="longleaf%20pine">longleaf pine</a> "Pinus palustris" and <a href="loblolly%20pine">loblolly pine</a> "P. taeda". In <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, most of the rosin is derived from live tapping of several species of <a href="pine">pine</a> trees, but mostly "<a href="Pinus%20oocarpa">Pinus oocarpa</a>", "<a href="Pinus%20leiophylla">Pinus leiophylla</a>", "<a href="Pinus%20devoniana">Pinus devoniana</a>" and "<a href="Pinus%20montezumae">Pinus montezumae</a>". Most production is concentrated in the west-central state of <a href="Michoac%C3%A1n">Michoacán</a>.
The main source of supply in <a href="Europe">Europe</a> is the <a href="France">French</a> district of <a href="Landes%20forest">Landes</a>, in the <a href="Departments%20of%20France">departments</a> of <a href="Gironde">Gironde</a> and <a href="Landes%20%28department%29">Landes</a>, where the <a href="maritime%20pine">maritime pine</a> "P. pinaster" is extensively cultivated. In the north of Europe, rosin is obtained from the <a href="Scots%20pine">Scots pine</a> "P. sylvestris", and throughout European countries local supplies are obtained from other species of pine, with <a href="Aleppo%20pine">Aleppo pine</a> "P. halepensis" being particularly important in the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> region.
Health effects.
The fumes released during soldering have been cited as a causative agent of <a href="occupational%20asthma">occupational asthma</a>. The symptoms also include <a href="desquamation">desquamation</a> of <a href="Bronchus">bronchial</a> <a href="epithelium">epithelium</a>.
